awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Alabama Alliance for Students with Disabilities in STEM
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Alabama Alliance for Students with Disabilities in STEM (AASD-STEM) was an NSF-Funded Alliance under the Research in Disabilities Education (RDE) program. The alliance was a collaborative effort involving Auburn University, Tuskegee University, Alabama State University, Auburn University, Montgomery, and Southern Union State Community College. Also involved as partners were the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind and six school districts in East-Central Alabama.

The Alliance worked to accomplish four major goals:

  1. Increase the quality of students with disabilities completing associate and baccalaureate degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines;
  2. Increase the number of students with disabilities completing associate and baccalaureate degrees in STEM disciplines and entering STEM graduate degree programs or the STEM workforce;
  3. Increase the number of students with disabilities completing graduate degrees in STEM disciplines;
  4. Increase the number of high school students with disabilities going to college.

Over the course of the project, the Alliance supported over 220 students with disabilities in STEM at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Using a Bridge retention model, the Alliance provided students with peer mentoring and mentoring from STEM faculty members, monthly large group meetings, weekly small group cluster meetings, research internship opportunities, annual research and advocacy conferences, and financial support applied towards tuition and fees.

Student outcomes include:

  • 138 research presentations given by 81 students
  • 121 completed Bachelor’s degrees
  • 68 summer research internships
  • 49 academic awards/honors
  • 17 completed graduate degrees (15 Masters of Science, 2 Doctors of Philosophy)
  • 4 student research publications
  • 1 patent

Alumni of the program have gone on to enter graduate STEM degree programs and many types of positions in the STEM workforce. Some positions held by AASD-STEM alumni include:

  • Software consultant at IBM
  • Android Developer at Utility Associates
  • Project Engineer at Hoar Construction
  • Lab Manager at Auburn University
  • Navy Civil Engineer Corps Officer
  • Research Assistant at HealthSouth
  • Software Developer at Greenway Medical Technologies
  • Android Developer at Utility Associates

Students also showed much improvement in academic self-efficacy and self-advocacy knowledge and behaviors. Some areas of statistically significant improvements include the following:

  • Explaining their academic and social strengths and weaknesses
  • Discussing challenges with other AASD-STEM students
  • Establishing meaningful connections with faculty
  • Establishing supportive peer relationships
  • Knowledge and interest in STEM research and employment opportunities
  • Academic self-efficacy and intention to persist in STEM
  • Increased self-advocacy knowledge and behavior frequency among participants
  • More students using Campus Disability Services

The AASD-STEM program served as the basis for the newly established South East Alliance for Persons with Disabilities in STEM (SEAPD-STEM), funded by the National Science Foundation’s INCLUDES program under award number 1649344. This new Alliance will expand the work of AASD-STEM from 5 institutions in Alabama to 21 institutions across the South East U.S. in 6 states and Washington, D.C. SEAPD-STEM aims to ensure the success of persons with disabilities in STEM at all levels, including undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and junior faculty members.


Last Modified: 12/08/2017
Modified by: Overtoun M Jenda
